Award.AwardTitle: Meso-Scale Behavior Characterization of "Tunable" Clay-Polymer Composites

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
Soils are natural materials. As such, their properties can vary greatly from location to location. This variability makes it difficult to predict or control the behavior of soil as a construction material. One approach to minimize this variability is to engineer a soil such that it performs in a predictable manner. This grant provides funding to investigate "tunable" clay-polymer composites in which the interparticle and/or interlayer spacings are controlled via a pH and ionic concentration-responsive polymer. This research will test the hypothesis that the pH- and ionic-concentration-induced manipulations previously observed at the particle level are also manifested at the meso-scale. The particular polymer used in this research is polyacrylamide, which is a widely available and inexpensive polymer often used for water treatment purposes. Meso-scale characterization of the clay-polymer composites will include measurement of swelling capacity; impact of repeated pH and ionic concentration cycling on hysteresis; changes in hydraulic conductivity with permeant pH and ionic concentration cycling; consolidation and shear wave velocity response under selected pH and ionic concentrations; and, shear strength under selected pH and ionic concentration conditions. The expected results from this work are: (1) a relationship between selected pH and ionic concentration environments and the degree of swell or shrink; (2) a relationship between selected pH and ionic concentration environments and response time of the material; (3) the composite response with selected pH and ionic concentration fluid cycling and any potential hysteresis; (4) demonstration of the "tunability" of the composites through hydraulic conductivity; (5) the relationship between the selected pH and ionic concentration environments and composite compressibility and shear wave velocity; and (6) shear strength properties of the composites when subjected to selected pH and ionic concentration conditions.

If successful, the results of this work will contribute to the establishment of a novel field of research: engineered soils using functional polymers. The development of tunable polymer-clay composites whose properties can be modified to maximize their efficient use will improve the performance of barrier systems, clay liners, filters, and contaminant removal systems. These engineered soils can be designed for specific applications, and improve performance of structures such as filters, impervious barriers (water or gas), and contaminant barriers. In terms of their economic impact, the overall cost of producing these clay-polymer composite soils is likely to be relatively low since both the production method and the polymer are inexpensive. If improved chemical and hydraulic stability is shown, then application in waste barrier systems could lead to reduced leachate and infiltration contamination. Polymer-clay composites may also be a more sustainable material for stabilizing impervious system applications. Increasing the lifespan of such structures would reduce energy needs related to re-building failed systems.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Meso-Scale Behavior Characterization of "Tunable" Clay-Polymer Composites: Project Outcomes

 The purpose of this research was to investigate the modifiable properties of “tunable” clay-polymer composites in which the spacing between clay particles (interparticle) and/or the spacing within a clay particle (interlayer) are controlled through chemical changes in the surrounding fluid.  The changes in spacings are accomplished using a responsive polymer, i.e. a polymer that contracts or extends in response to changes in the surrounding environment, such as change in pH or ionic (salt) concentration (Figure 1).  It is envisioned that clay soils treated with responsive polymers have great potential as an innovative geo-material for a wide variety of applications in which there is a need for the material or exposed surface area to be modified over time.  The results of this work contribute further to the establishment of a novel field of research:  engineered soils using functional polymers.  This developing field of research will lead to a broader approach to engineering practices. 

 The fundamental phenomena investigated in this project under selected pH and ionic concentrations include (1) clay mineral type (kaolinite and montmorillonite; Figure 2), (2) swelling capacities, (3) the impact of altering pH and ionic concentration conditions on the material response, (4) the ease with which water can flow through the material when subjected to varying chemical cycling, and (6) strength.

 Intellectual Merit Outcomes.  This work aimed to characterize a modifiable clay-polymer composite material, the properties of which are “tunable” by changes in the surrounding fluid chemistry. The main contributions from this work are:  (1) composite particle interactions are a function of pH and ionic concentration, (2) the strength of the clay-polymer composites are greater than the strength of the pure clay materials, (3) the montmorillonite-based composite swells less than pure montmorillonite, and (4) the fluid permeability is a function of the surrounding fluid chemistry. The tunable response was maximized when the composite exposed to high ionic concentration test solutions (coiled conformation) compared to pH solutions. However, the “tunability” of the synthesized composite may be limited in certain cases, for example, when external stimuli changes the conformation of polymer molecules from extended conformation to partially extended.

 Broader Impact Outcomes

  • Advance Discovery and Understanding While Promoting Teaching, Training and Learning. The results of this work have been incorporated into the University of Tennessee’s undergraduate and graduate programs. Project techniques and results were used to develop a course module on soil modification and enhancement techniques. One Ph.D. student, one Master’s student, and four undergraduate students contributed to the completion of this project.  These students were mentored by the PI in teaching and research activities.
  • Broaden Participation of Underrepresented Groups. The PI collaborated with the Tennessee Louis Stokes Alliance for Minority Participation program to identify under-representative minority undergraduate students to work on this project. TLSAMP’s goal is to increase the pool of talented Science, Technology, Engineering, and Mathematics (STEM) graduates capable of pursuing graduate studies, while increasing the underrepresented population in the STEM fields. TLSAMP focuses on recruitment, retention, and graduate school preparation. Two of the undergraduate researchers came from this program.
  • Broad Dissemination to Enhance Scientific and Technological Understanding. The Ph.D. student and PI have written three manuscripts based on this work to be submitted to peer-reviewed journals.  The undergraduate and Master’s students also contributed to this effort. Three of the undergraduate students presented their contributions at a university-wide research competition, and one student was awarded second place. 
  • Benefits to Society. This research represents the next generation of engineered soils that can be altered both at the space and time scales. These engineered soils can be designed for specific applications and improve performance of structures such as filters, impervious barriers (water or gas), and contaminant barriers. The overall cost of producing these clay-polymer composite soils is relatively low since both the production method and the polymer are inexpensive. Based on the obtained results, these materials show promise for application in waste barrier systems that could lead to reduced leached and infiltration contamination. Polymer-clay composites may be a more sustainable material for stable impervious system applications. Increasing the lifespan of such structures would reduce energy needs related to re-building failed systems.
